choices.text: The anterior superior iliac spine & pubic symphysis lie in the same coronal plane
The pelvic surface of pubic symphysis faces backwards and upwards
The plane of pelvic inlet make an angle of 50-60 degree with horizontal plane
The plane of pelvic outlet makes an angle of 75 degree with horizontal plane

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect for anatomical position of bony pelvis ?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation :

Option A, B and C statements are correct for anatomical position of bony pelvis.

Option D : The plane of pelvic outlet makes an angle of 15 degree with horizontal.

Bony Pelvis Overview

  • Formation: The bony pelvis consists of 4 bones united at 4 joints:
    • Bones: Two hip bones (anteriorly and laterally), sacrum, and coccyx (posteriorly).
    • Joints:
      • Two sacroiliac joints
      • Pubic symphysis
      • Sacrococcygeal joint

Anatomical Position of the Pelvis

  • Coronal Plane Alignment: The anterior superior iliac spine and pubic symphysis lie in the same coronal plane.
  • Pelvic Surface Orientation: The pelvic surface of the pubic symphysis faces backwards and upwards.
  • Pelvic Inlet Angle: The plane of the pelvic inlet makes an angle of 50-60 degrees with the horizontal plane.
  • Pelvic Outlet Angle: The plane of the pelvic outlet makes an angle of 15 degrees with the horizontal plane.
  • Sacral Canal Direction: The upper end of the sacral canal is directed almost directly upwards.

Key takeaways : The bony pelvis is formed by two hip bones, the sacrum, and coccyx, connected by two sacroiliac joints, the pubic symphysis, and the sacrococcygeal joint.

choices.text: Sacral promontory to upper border of pubic symphysis
Sacral promontory to lower border of pubic symphysis
Spine of L5 vertebra to upper border of Pubic symphysis

questions.text: The true conjugate is measured from which of the following points ?
questions.solution:
Option-wise Explanation of Pelvic Measurements

  • Option A: Interischial Spinous Diameter
    • Definition: Measurement from ischial spine to ischial spine.
    • Length: Approximately 9 cm.
  • Option B: True Conjugate
    • Definition: Measurement from sacral promontory to the upper border of pubic symphysis.
    • Calculation: It is derived by deducting 1.5 to 2 cm from the diagonal conjugate.
  • Option C: Diagonal Conjugate
    • Definition: Measurement from sacral promontory to the lower border of pubic symphysis.
    • Length: Approximately 11.5 cm.
  • Option D: External Conjugate
    • Definition: Measurement from the spine of L5 vertebra to the upper border of pubic symphysis.
    • Length: Approximately 19 cm.

Key takeaways:

choices.text: Width of body of 1st sacral vertebra to ala of sacrum
Maximum length to ala of sacrum
Maximum breadth to width of body of 1st sacral vertebra

questions.text: Which of the following ratio is expressed as sacral index ?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation :

Option B, C and D are incorrect ratio for sacral index.

Option A : Ratio of Maximum breadth across base to maximum length from promontory to apex is expressed as sacral index.

The average sacral index is about 105 in male and 115 in female.

Sex difference in sacrum :

The width of the body of first sacral vertebra is greater than that of each ala in the male. In female, the two are equal.

The dorsal concavity of auricular surface is less marked in male.

The concavity on ventral aspect of sacrum is more uniform and is shallower in male. In female, the concavity is irregular especially between S1 and S2 and between S3 and S4.

The sacrovertebral angle is more prominent in female and downward direction of pelvic surface is greater than in male.

Key takeaways:

choices.text: It is done in last 5 days of Menstrual cycle
It is used to study shape and size of uterus and uterine tube
The iodized oil (lipiodol) is used in it
The spillage of dye into peritoneal cavity indicate patent uterine tube

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect for given radiological method?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation:

The given radiological method is Hysterosalpingography.

Option B, C and D are correct statements for Hysterosalpingography.

Option A : It is done in first 5 -10 days of menstrual cycle.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG)

  • Definition: A radiological method used to visualize the uterus and uterine tubes, confirming their patency. The resulting image is called a hysterosalpingogram.
  • Timing:
    • Correct: The procedure is ideally performed within the first 5 to 10 days of the menstrual cycle to avoid interference from a possible pregnancy.
  • Procedure:
    • A tight cannula is introduced into the internal os of the cervix.
    • The cannula is connected to a syringe, and 5 to 10 ml of iodized oil (lipiodol) is injected.
    • Skiagram (radiograph) is taken to assess the shape and size of the uterus and uterine tubes.
  • Observations:
    • Shape and size of the uterus and uterine tubes are evaluated.
    • Spilling of the dye into the peritoneal cavity is noted, indicating patency of the tubes.

Key takeaways :

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a radiological procedure that visualizes the uterus and uterine tubes using iodized oil to confirm patency, preferably performed within the first 5 to 10 days of the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: A 50 years old male with past history of chronic gastro oesophageal reflux disease (GERD) visited to hospital with complaint of worsening heartburn and regurgitation. On upper GI endoscopy , doctor found herniation of stomach through oesophageal hiatus of diaphragm. What is the most probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation :

Option A: Sliding hiatal hernia : It occurs when the gastroesophageal junction and part of stomach slide up into chest through the oesophageal hiatus. It is the most common type of hiatal hernia and often associated with GERD, leading to symptoms like heartburn and regurgitation.

Option B: Morgagni hernia: It is rare congenital hernia that occurs in anterior part of diaphragm through foramen of Morgagni. The herniated contents are usually omentum or transverse colon rather than stomach. They often present in childhood.

Option C: Bochdalek hernia : It is congenital hernia and occur posterolaterally. They are common on left side and present in infancy with respiratory distress due to herniation of abdominal contents into thoracic cavity. In adults, it is rare and less likely to be associated with GERD symptoms.

Option D: Diaphragmatic eventration: It is a condition where part of diaphragm is abnormally elevated but intact. It can mimics a hernia on imaging but typically does not involve actual herniation of abdominal contents through diaphragmatic defect.

Key takeaways:

A sliding hiatal hernia occurs when the gastroesophageal junction and part of the stomach slide into the chest through the esophageal hiatus, often causing GERD symptoms like heartburn and regurgitation.

questions.solution:
Option wise explanation:

Option A, B and C: are structures that pass through aortic opening.

Option D: Phrenic nerve: pass through vena caval opening of diaphragm.

Key takeaways:

Major openings of thoracoabdominal diaphragm:

choices.text: Medial : Levator ani and external anal sphincter

questions.text: Which of the following pair is incorrect for boundaries of Ischiorectal fossa ?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation:

Option A, B and D: pair is correct for boundaries of Ischiorectal fossa.

Option C: lateral boundaries: Obturator internus with obturator fascia.

Ischiorectal fossa:

It is a wedge shaped space situated on each side of anal canal below pelvic diaphragm.

  • Length: 5 cm
  • Width: 2.5 cm
  • Depth: 5 to 6.2 cm.

Boundaries:

Key takeaways:

The ischiorectal fossa is a wedge-shaped space around 5 cm long, 2.5 cm wide, and 5 to 6.2 cm deep, located on each side of the anal canal and bounded by various pelvic structures.

questions.text: A 20 year old boy met with the accident and came to hospital with rupture of penile part of urethra. All of the following sites has extravasation of urine except
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation:

Option A, C and D: are sites for superficial extravasation of urine in rupture of penile part of urethra.

Option B: Ischiorectal fossa: does not has extravasation of urine.

Rupture of the urethra: leads to extravasation of urine, which may be superficial or deep.

In superficial extravasation:

  • The urine spreads downwards deep to membranous layer of the superficial fascia.
  • It first fills the superficial perineal space; and then scrotum, the penis and the lower part of anterior abdominal wall.
  • It is prevented from going to the ischioanal fossa or the thigh by the firm attachment of the membranous layer of superficial fascia to their boundaries.

In deep extravasation:

The urine spreads upwards into the extraperitoneal space of the pelvis around bladder and prostate into anterior abdominal wall.

Key takeaways:

Rupture of the urethra causes urine extravasation, which can be superficial, filling the perineal space and genitalia, or deep, spreading into the extraperitoneal space around the bladder and prostate.

choices.text: It is lined by the transitional epithelium
Its upper part receive blood supply from renal artery
It enters the pelvis by crossing in front of termination of common iliac artery
It is supplied by T5 -T8 segments

questions.text: All of the following statements are true for ureter except
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation :

Option A, B and C are true statements for Ureter.

Option D : Ureter is supplied by sympathetic from T10 to L1 segments and parasympathetic from S2 to S4 segments.

Ureter

  • Structure: Pair of narrow, thick-walled muscular tubes that convey urine from the kidneys to the urinary bladder.
  • Length: Approximately 25 cm long, with the upper half located in the abdomen and the lower half in the pelvis.
  • Origin: Begins within the renal sinus as a funnel-shaped dilatation called the renal pelvis.
  • Pathway:
    • Passes downwards and medially along the tip of the transverse process and psoas major muscle.
    • Enters the pelvis by crossing in front of the termination of the common iliac artery.
  • Constriction Points: The ureter is slightly constricted at five places.

Blood Supply

  • Upper Part: Supplied by branches from the renal artery.
  • Middle Part: Supplied by branches from the aorta.
  • Pelvic Part: Supplied by branches from the vesical and middle rectal artery.

Nerve Supply

  • Sympathetic: From T10 to L1 segments.
  • Parasympathetic: From S2 to S4 nerves.

Key takeaways :

  • The ureters are 25 cm long muscular tubes that transport urine from the kidneys to the bladder, originating from the renal pelvis, crossing the common iliac artery, and receiving blood supply from the renal artery, aorta, and pelvic branches, with nerve innervation from T10 to L1 and S2 to S4.

choices.text: At the brim of lesser pelvis

questions.text: All of the following are normal constrictions of ureter except
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation :

Option A, B and C : are the site where ureter is slightly constricted.

Option D : The ureter is not constricted at crossing of root of mesentery.

Normal constrictions of Ureter :

The ureter is slightly constricted at five places:

  1. At the pelviureteric junction.
  2. At the brim of the lesser pelvis.
  3. Crossing by ductus deferens or broad ligament of uterus.
  4. Its oblique passage through the bladder wall.
  5. At its opening in lateral angle of trigone.

Key takeaways:

The ureter is slightly constricted at five points: the pelviureteric junction, the brim of the lesser pelvis, where it crosses the ductus deferens or broad ligament, its oblique passage through the bladder wall, and at its opening in the lateral angle of the trigone.

questions.text: A 40 years old male patient visited to hospital with complaint of involuntary urination. He has history of spinal cord injury at T11 level in accident a month ago. He is unable to voluntarily initiate urination and he experience involuntary bladder constrictions leading to urine leakage especially when bladder is full. What is the diagnosis in this case ?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation:

Option A: Autonomic reflex bladder : is correct diagnosis. Automatic reflex bladder occurs in patient with spinal cord injuries above sacral micturition center leading to upper motor neuron lesion. This condition causes the bladder to empty reflexively when it becomes full, without voluntary control.

Option B: Atonic bladder: is incorrect because an Atonic bladder occurs with lower motor neuron lesions, leading to a flaccid bladder that cannot contract properly , resulting in urinary retention rather than involuntary leakage.

Option C: Cauda equina syndrome: is incorrect as it is lower motor neuron lesion leading to flaccid bladder.

Option D: Stress incontinence: is incorrect as stress incontinence is related to weakened pelvic floor muscles not a spinal cord injury.

Key takeaways:

Autonomic reflex bladder results from upper motor neuron lesions causing involuntary reflexive emptying of the bladder, while atonic bladder occurs due to lower motor neuron lesions, leading to urinary retention and inability to contract properly.

choices.text: It receive parasympathetic innervation from nervi erigentes
It receive sympathetic innervation from T12 to L2
The sympathetic innervation is responsible for detrusor muscle contraction
The somatic pudendal nerve supplies sphincter urethrae which is voluntary

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the nerve supply of urinary bladder is incorrect ?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation:

Option A, B and D: are correct statements for nerve supply of urinary bladder.

Option C: The sympathetic innervation is responsible for detrusor muscle relaxation.

Nerve Supply of the Urinary Bladder

  • Vesical Plexus: The urinary bladder is supplied by the vesical plexus, composed of fibers from the inferior hypogastric plexus. It contains both sympathetic and parasympathetic components, with motor (efferent) and sensory (afferent) fibers.

Components:

  • Parasympathetic Efferent Fibers:
    • Origin: S2, S3, S4.
    • Function: Motor to the detrusor muscle, facilitating bladder contraction.
  • Sympathetic Efferent Fibers:
    • Origin: T11 to L2.
    • Function:
      • Inhibitory to the detrusor muscle (relaxes bladder).
      • Motor to the pre-prostatic sphincter mechanism.
  • Somatic Nerve Supply:
    • Pudendal Nerve (S2-S4): Supplies the sphincter urethrae, which is voluntary and located within the urethral wall.
  • Sensory Nerves:
    • Responsible for pain sensations due to distension or spasm of the bladder wall, primarily carried by parasympathetic nerves and partly by sympathetic nerves.

Key takeaways:

The urinary bladder is innervated by the vesical plexus, with parasympathetic fibers (S2-S4) stimulating the detrusor muscle, sympathetic fibers (T11-L2) inhibiting the detrusor, and sensory fibers conveying pain from distension.

choices.text: Loss of voluntary control over defecation
Loss of sensation of rectal distension

questions.text: The damage to autonomic nerves supplying the rectum result into
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation:

Option A: Haemorrhoids: is related with saccular dilatation of rectal venous plexus.

Option B: Rectal prolapse: is due to weakened pelvic floor muscles.

Option C: Voluntary control over defecation: is governed by somatic nerves .

Option D: is correct . Autonomic nerves are responsible for sensing rectal fullness and triggering the urge to defecate.

Nerve supply of rectum:

  • The rectum is supplied by both sympathetic (L1,L2) and parasympathetic (S2,3,4) nerves through superior rectal or inferior mesenteric and inferior hypogastric plexuses.
  • Sympathetic nerves are vasomotor, inhibitory to rectal musculature and motor to internal sphincter.
  • Parasympathetic nerves are motor to musculature of rectum and inhibitory to internal sphincter.
  • Sensation of distension of rectum pass through parasympathetic nerves while pain sensations are carried by both sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves.

Key takeaways:

The rectum receives sympathetic (L1, L2) and parasympathetic (S2, S3, S4) innervation, with sympathetic fibers inhibiting rectal musculature and motor to the internal sphincter, and parasympathetic fibers stimulating rectal musculature and carrying sensations of distension and pain.

questions.text: A 30 years old male visited surgeon with complaint of sharp severe pain during defecation from few days . He had a history of constipation since few months. He has no significant medical history. On physical examination doctor noted a small tear at posterior midline of anal canal. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Option-wise Explanation:

  • Option A: Hemorrhoids
    • Incorrect: While hemorrhoids can cause bleeding, they usually do not result in severe pain during defecation.
  • Option B: Anal Fistula
    • Incorrect: Anal fistulas typically present with pus discharge rather than sharp pain during defecation.
  • Option C: Anal Fissure
    • Correct: Anal fissures present with sharp pain during defecation, often accompanied by a small tear at the posterior midline of the anal canal.
  • Option D: Rectal Prolapse
    • Incorrect: Rectal prolapse is characterized by the protrusion of rectal tissue from the anus, not pain during defecation.

Key takeaways :

Anal fissure :

  • is caused by rupture of one of the anal valves, usually by the passage of dry hard stool in constipated person.
  • Each valve is lined with mucous membrane above and with skin below .
  • Because of involvement of skin, the condition is extremely painful and is associated with marked spasm of the anal sphincters.

choices.text: Absence of valves in superior rectal and portal veins
Poor support from surrounding loose connective tissue
Compression of veins at sites where they pierce muscular coat of rectum
Rupture of one of the anal valves

questions.text: All of the following are factors that responsible for causing piles/Haemorrhoids except
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation:

Option A, B and C are the various factors that are responsible for causing internal piles.

Option D: Rupture of anal valves leads to anal fissure.

Piles/Haemorrhoids:

Piles are saccular dilatation of internal rectal venous plexus.

They bleed profusely during staining at stool.

The primary piles occurs in 3,7, and 11 o' clock positions of anal wall.

They are formed by enlargement of three main radicles of superior rectal vein which lie in anal columns, which occupy left lateral, right posterior and right anterior positions.

The various factors responsible for causing piles are :

  • Poor support to veins from surrounding loose connective tissue.
  • Absence of valves in superior rectal and portal veins.
  • Compression of veins at sites where they pierce the muscular coat of rectum.
  • Direct transmission of increased portal pressure at portosystemic communications.

Key takeaways:

Piles are dilated internal rectal venous plexuses that bleed during bowel movements, primarily at the 3, 7, and 11 o'clock positions, caused by enlarged superior rectal vein radicles and factors like poor support, lack of valves, compression, and increased portal pressure.

questions.text: A 20 years old male came to emergency department with complaint of sudden onset of severe pain in left testicle since 2 hours. He had no history of trauma or fever. On examination left testicle is tender on palpation and cremasteric reflex is absent on left side. What is the diagnosis in above case ?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation:

Option B: Varicocele: is incorrect as it usually presents as painless , "bag of worms" feeling in the scrotum and does not cause acute severe pain or absent cremasteric reflex.

Option C: Hydrocele: is incorrect as it presents as painless swelling of one or both testicle.

Option D: Epididymitis: is incorrect as it presents with gradual onset of pain, often associated with fever and dysuria and the cremasteric reflex is usually intact.

Option A: Testicular torsion: is correct as it is characterized by sudden onset of severe testicular pain, elevated testicle and absent cremasteric reflex.

Key takeaways:

Testicular torsion is a medical emergency characterized by the twisting of the spermatic cord, which cuts off the blood supply to the affected testis, leading to severe pain, swelling, and potential loss of the testis if not treated promptly.

questions.text: Which of the following match is incorrect for given image ?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation:

Option A, B and C are correct match.

Option D : label 4 is Coccygeus muscle.

Pelvic Muscles

  1. Rotators of the Hip Joint:
    • Piriformis: A short muscle that assists in lateral rotation of the hip.
    • Obturator Internus: Also a short muscle that aids in lateral rotation of the hip.
  2. Pelvic Diaphragm:
    • Levator Ani: Forms a significant part of the pelvic diaphragm, supporting pelvic organs.
    • Coccygeus: Complements the levator ani to form the pelvic diaphragm, separating the pelvis from the perineum.

Key takeaways :

The pelvic diaphragm consists of the levator ani, which includes the pubococcygeus, iliococcygeus, and puborectalis muscles that support pelvic organs and maintain continence, and the coccygeus muscle, which stabilizes the coccyx and supports the pelvic floor.

choices.text: It is smaller terminal branch of common iliac artery
It does not gives visceral branch from its anterior division
It supplies pelvic organs, perineum and iliac fossa
It begins in front of sacroiliac joint and ends near upper surface of greater sciatic notch

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct for internal iliac artery except
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation :

Option A, C and D : are correct statements for internal iliac artery.

Option B : It does not give visceral branch from its posterior division.

Internal iliac artery:

  • It is the smaller terminal branch of the common iliac artery. It is 3.75 cm long.
  • It supplies Pelvic organs, perineum, greater part of gluteal region and iliac fossa.
  • It begins in front of sacroiliac joint, at level of 5th lumbar vertebra.
  • It runs downwards and backwards and ends near upper margin of greater sciatic notch by dividing into anterior and posterior divisions.

Key takeaways:

Branches:

questions.text: A 65 years old male patient visited hospital with complaint of difficulty urinating , weak urinary stream and pain in perineum. He also had a low back pain since 2 months. On per rectal examination, doctor found hard and fixed mass anteriorly. What is most probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Option A: Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia

  • Incorrect: Typically presents as an enlarged, non-fixed prostate; however, the examination revealed a hard and fixed mass.

Option B: Prostatitis

  • Description: Inflammation of the prostate characterized by pain during urination, ejaculation, and bowel movements.

Option C: Bladder Carcinoma

  • Description: Often presents with hematuria (blood in urine) and painful urination.

Option D: Prostatic Carcinoma

  • Correct: Symptoms include difficulty urinating and perineal pain. On examination, it is palpable as a hard and fixed mass. Metastatic spread can occur to the vertebral column, presenting as low back pain.

Key takeaways:

The most probable diagnosis for the 65-year-old male patient with difficulty urinating, weak urinary stream, perineal pain, low back pain, and a hard, fixed mass on rectal examination is prostatic carcinoma, as these symptoms and findings are indicative of malignancy.

choices.text: Para mesonephric duct : Appendix of testis

questions.solution:

Option A, B and D: are correct pair for embryonic structure and its derivatives in female urogenital structure.

Option C: Para mesonephric duct derivatives in female : Uterus, cervix, fallopian tubes, upper part of vagina.

Key takeaways:
